div1.ab: To, The Right Honorable Earl Granville K.G. Her Majesty's Principal Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs,-
div1.p: My Lord, Having carefully considered the report of our affairs with the French Government which has lately appeared in its "Documents Diplomatiques," we beg to submit to Your Lordship's friendly attention the following few brief notes which we feel are alike demanded by the interests of truth and the welfare of our cause.

With regard to the correspondence of more bau- dais, we shall not trespass upon you time by deny- ing in detail the many misrepresentations thereon made. It was not to be expected that his letters would give a unprejudiced account of the state of affairs between France and Madagascar. But we did look forwad to finding a fair historical ecord of our dealings with French officials at Paris in the Government document already referred to, and are sorry to be compilled to assert that such, record has not been given.

Permit us to remind Your Lordship of what we have already had the honour of stating in our communication of 9th December 1882 with regard to the manner in which our business was transae- -ted in Paris.

Except at the very beginning of the negotiations our affairs were not dealt with by those who had
been

been officially appointed to discuss them on the part of France. In all the attempts to come to an understanding the French Goverment was represented by intermediaries who we have reason to believe con- ducted the business with their own personal advan- tage chiefly in view. -By these gentlemen we were given to understand that there was not the slightest hope of avoiding immediate hostilities with France except by making some concession to the National pride. We had clearly refused to acknowledge the claim to a Protectorate in our Note to mess- les Commercial (No. 23 of Documents Deplomatiques) on the subject, and continued to do so throughout. But on being promised by the intermediaries that a temporary removal of our new Custom Houses from the North West Coast, and an offer to grant long leases of land would lead to a withdrawal of the threatened protectorate, we verbally expressed our willingness, thus to meet the French Government halfway;-our conversa- tions at this time we taken by the intermediaries + made up by them into the Notes No. 24+26 of "Document Diplomatiques," which we do not admit as correct interpretations of our meaning.

Our last words to the intermediaries on this subject were to the effect that the removal of the Custom Houses was to be distinctly re- garded as only temporary. We were also assured that after these verbal agreement had been placed upon paper we should have an opportunity of reconsidering them before being expected to affix our signatures.

The next event was our being asked by mon= seicaers Duelue through a Government desk to
sign

sign a document which has since receied the name of "Ultimatum" to which we specifically desire to call Your Lordship's attention. it is not reproduced in its original integrity in No.27 of "Document Diplo- matiques" but is given in a manned calculated to create an unfavorable opinion of our refusal to sign it.

In the published report a whole paragraph has been omitted the very portion to which our re- fusal attached itself as being contrary to what we had been led to expect as the of making concessions to National pride.-The omitted paragraph reads " Il est bien entendre ete," and will befound in the copy of the original document which we have the honor of now enclosing for Your Lordships inspection.-

In the face of such an unjust misrepresen- tation, unprecedented we would hope in the transactions of civilized Government, it seems a small matter to call Your Lordship notivr to the incorrect statement made by Monsieur Baudais to which we have already referred.

But the more we examine his misleading language, the more we discover the unworthy ill- feeling which prompted its use, and hence we venture to ask Your Loedship to give a moments consideration to the comments we have made thereupon in the copy of the "Documents Diplomatiques" which accompanies the present letter.

We have the honor to be, with the highest consi- deration.
My Lord Your Lordship's most obedient servant (signed) Ravoninahitriniarivo (signed) Ramaniraka
